div.p: THE PROLOGUE TO CALISTHO, WITH THE CHORUS'S BETWEEN THE ACTS.
LONDON, Printed in the Year MDCLXXV.

div.head: PROLOGUE. The Curtain is drawn up, and there appears a Nymph leaning on an Ʋrne, repreſenting the River Thames, attended by two Nymphs, repreſenting Peace and Plenty: Near her are the four Parts of the World ſeeming to make offerings to Her: On the opening of the Scene, lamenting voices are heard on both ſides of the Theatre, at which, the Nymph of the River ſeems affrigtned.

p.hi: Fly, Fly, Help, Oh! Help or we dye.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: WHat mournful cries are theſe on ev'ry ſide!
The Winds waſt nothing to this Iſland o're
But the complainings of ſome Neighbr'ing Shore,
And all the Ecchoes are in groans employ'd.

The fair London anciently ſo called.
Auguſta too, I weeping ſee,
Though none ſo fair, ſo rich, ſo great as She;
Alas! my Fears encreaſe:
You gentle Nymphs of Plenty and of Peace,
Shall now go ſeek ſome other Shore.
And you that with your Preſents wait,
Shall bring your gifts no more.

sp.speaker: Plen.
sp.l: I to no other Dwelling will betake,

sp.speaker: Pea.
sp.l: Thy beautious Streams I never will forſake,

sp.speaker: Euro.
sp.l: And we our Preſents ſtill will make.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: We our preſents ſtill will make.

sp.speaker: Ple.
sp.l: Thy ſtores with all my Plenty ſhall be fill'd.

sp.speaker: Pea.
sp.l: My Halcion on thy Banks her Neſt ſhall build.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt in all my nobleſt Arts be skill'd.

sp.speaker: Aſi.
sp.l: My Jewels ſhall adorn no Brow but Thine.

sp.speaker: Amer.
sp.l: Thy Lovers in my Gold ſhall ſhine.

sp.speaker: Afri.
sp.l: Thou for thy Slaves, ſhalt have theſe
Scorched Sons of mine.

sp.speaker: Pea. Pleu.
sp.l: Thy beautious ſtreams we never will forſake.

sp.speaker: Euro. Aſi. Afr. Amer.
sp.l: And we our preſents ſtill will make.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: We our preſents ſtill will make.

sp.speaker: Pea.
sp.l: What ſhould ſo much Beauty fear,
Round this Iſle the Heavens appear
Like your own ſtreams, all undiſturb'd and clear:

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Theſe beautious Nymphs unfrightned too,
Not minding what on other Shores they do,
Their innocent delights purſue.

sp.speaker: Pea.
sp.l: See, They (void of grief or fear)
Come to entertain you here.

div.stage: Enter Nymphs, who Dance, and go off.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Oh! now my Spirits I recover,
I've wak'd the Genius of this Iſle, my War-like Lover.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: What cries are theſe diſturb my pleaſing Reſt?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: 'Tis I, (my Love) 'tis I, thy ayde requeſt.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Is it my Nymph, what doſt thou fear?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Does not my Love ſad cries round him hear?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Wilt thou thy fear at every ſhriek proclaim?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Am I alone to blame?
Do you not ſee Augusta, rich and fair,
(Though to her Lap, I all my Treaſure bear)
Will for no comfort ſtay her Tears?
Auguſta is inclin'd to fears.
Be ſhe full, or be ſhe wayning,
Still Auguſta is complaining.
Give her all you can to eaſe Her,
You ſhall never, never pleaſe Her.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Theſe fears do not belong to Her nor You;
Europe only ſhould lament,
The Nymphs of his fair Continent.
But this ſweet Iſle no Monſter can invade.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Oh ſend thoſe poor diſtreſſed Nymphs ſome Aid.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: From the mild power of this happy place.
Who is inclin'd,
To make the World as peaceful as his mind,
They have already gain'd the grace:
Two Heroes of his own coeleſtial Race
Are ſent; the one to Triumph o're the Seas,
And all the watery Divinities.
The other, Monſters of the Land to quell,
And make the Nymphs in ſafety dwell.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: The firſt, in War has all perfections gain'd,
That can by humane nature be attain'd:
The ſecond promiſes, to be
All that in the firſt we ſee.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Mars to the firſt does all his glory lend:
The ſecond Beauty, Youth, and Love attend.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Both in high perfections ſhine:
Valour, Glory, race Divine:
Wait a while, and you ſhall ſee
Both return with Victory.

sp.speaker: Pea.
sp.l: Hark, hark; the Triumph's near,
And ſee! they both already crown'd appear.

div.stage: Enter One crown'd with a Naval Crown, attended by Sea-gods and Tritons.

sp.l: Rejoyce you watry Deities:
The mighty Monſters of the Seas,
This valiant Prince has ſlain.
The God of this fair Iſle ſhall now,
Command (as all his Right allow)
The Empire of the Mayne.

div.stage: Enter one Crown'd with a Mural Crown, attended by Warriours.

sp.l: Ye Gods and Nymphs of Plains and Groves;
Of Springs and Streams, enjoy your Loves:
This youthful Hero has ſubdu'd,
The Satyrs now of ev'ry Wood:
Has kill'd or ta'n e'm all for Slaves,
And chac'd the Gyants from their Caves.
Cho. of all. Let us both their praiſes ſing,
Whilſt we both in Triumph bring,
Let us all contend to grace e'm
With our loud, and joyfull'ſt thanks,
Whilſt upon the flow'ry banks,
Of this beautious Nymph we place e'm.

div.stage: Two Entries are Danc'd: One of Sea-gods and the other of Warriours.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Now welcom Heroes to my bleſt abode,
And to my Nymph belov'd by ev'ry God.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Welcom to my Love and me,
Now we all ſhall happy be.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Now we all ſhall happy be.

sp.speaker: Ple.
sp.l: Now you whoſe valour gives the World repoſe,
See what Fame on you beſtows.
Her ſhining Temple ſhall preſerve your names,
And thence her Trumpet your renown proclaims.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: To our Divinity now let us go,
And at his Feet your Crowns and Trophies throw.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: I will my thanks in Offerings proclaim.

sp.speaker: Aſi.
sp.l: I'le lend you Spice.

sp.speaker: Amer.
sp.l: I Gold.

sp.speaker: Afr.
sp.l: And I the ſame.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: I'le be your Guide.
My Streams beneath his Palace ſlide.
There it is not far before you,
Pleaſure, Arts, Religion, Glory,
Warm'd by his propitious Smile,
Flouriſh there, and bleſs this Iſle.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: But ſtay! Turning to the King and Queen. what wonder does my Spirit ſeize?
See! here are both the great Divinities.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: The God and Goddeſs too of this bleſs'd Iſle!
Chaſt Beauty in her aſpect ſhines,
And Love in his does ſmile.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Quickly (Heroes) as 'tis meet,
Throw your Trophies at their Feet.
Fall down, and adore e'm.
Whilſt with ſpeed we hither call,
The Gods of neighbr'ing Groves, and all
Their Nymphs to dance before e'm.

div.stage: Enter Rural Gods and Nymphs, and Dance.
When the Prologue is done, and all gone off the Stage, Enter Two, who ſing this Song.

l.hi: Now for the Play, the Prologue is done,
The Dancing is o're, and the Singers are gone.
The Ladies ſo fine, and ſo fair it ſurpaſſes,
Are dreſs'd, and have all tak'n leave of their glaſſes.
Where are the Slaves ſhould make ready the Stage?
Here, here are the ſlaves ſhould make ready the Stage.

div.stage: The Song to the Minovet, Danced in the Prologue, to be ſung by Shepheards.
div.l: Happy we Swaines, who are young and have leiſure,
And but the wit our advantage to know.
We do not need either Fortune or Treaſure,
Love and Delight with the youthful will go.
Coyeſt of Nymphs may be won to the pleaſure,
By Shepheards who love, and have youth to beſtow.
Then whilſt we are young, let's to pleaſure betake us,
Each Swain with his Nymph, and each Nymph with her Swain
Embrace, and be happy as Loving can make us,
And ſo make the moſt of our youth that we can.

div.head: Chorus after the Firſt Act.
div.stage: Enter Strephon, Corydon, Daphne, Sylvia. Cho. of Shepheards.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Hark, hark, I hear the merry Hunters Horn,

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: The ſound from yonder Hill by winds is born.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Diana, and her Nymphs are all that way A Hunting gone

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: So ſoon e're break of day.
Let e'm let e'm go.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Lovers, better pleaſures know.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Let the cold Nymphs run dabling in the Dew,
Kind Love to warmer pleaſures us invites

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: I do not envy their delights,
Whilſt my dear Strephon does continue true.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Whilſt thus ſevere my Sylvia does remain,
I envy not the Hunters, but the ſlain.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Poor Corydon, thy flame remove,
I pity thee, but cannot love.
Yet I own, I have ſomething in every Vein;
Which moves me to Love, could I meet with a Swain,
Who were to my mind, and would love me again.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: See Shepheards the day is begun:
Come, with our ſports let's welcom the Sun.

div.stage: Shepheards Dance to this following Song.

l.hi: Kind Lovers, Love on,
Leaſt the World be undone,
And Mankind be lost by Degrees.
For if all from their Loves,
Should go wander in Groves,
There ſoon would be nothing but Trees.

div.head: Chorus after the Second Act.
div.stage: Enter Strephon, Corydon, Daphne, Sylvia, Chorus of Shepheards. The Scene near the Vale, whither the Winds carryed Caliſtho.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Come Shepheards, quickly haſten to the ſhades,
The Sun with all his force the Air invades.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: The open plains let us forſake,
Here is a Grove will pity of us take.
The Trees in gentle whiſperings invite us,
Here are all things to delight us.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Theſe pleaſures none can well improve,
But we (my Shepherdeſs) who love.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Theſe pleaſures none can well improve,
But we (my deareſt Swain) who love.

sp.speaker: Corid.
sp.l: Oh happy Shepheard, and kind Shepherdeſs,
Whom all the Gods, above expreſſion bleſs.
Here Sylvia cruel, I forlorn,
Torment our ſelves each day.
Whilſt I with grief, and ſhe with ſcorn,
Waſt all our youth away.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Alas poor Shepheard! the fault is not mine,
That to thy paſſion I do not incline,
I wiſh thy love and deſert were more moving,
For I confeſs I fain would be loving.
What (on the ſuddain) do I ayle?
Gentle winds from yonder Vale,
On the ſuddain warm my Heart.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Oh! I'm wounded: Oh! I ſmart.

sp.speaker: Sire.
sp.l: Sure ſome God is here deſcended,
With a Train of Loves attended.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Oh! I'm wounded: Oh! I Love.
This is ſome inchanted Grove.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: This is ſome inchanted Grove.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Oh! my Soul is in a flame.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: I muſt fly or loſe my Fame,

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O what raging Paſſions fill me!
Love me Sylvia now, or kill me.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Oh! I love, and long to ſhew it,
But my Shepheard ſhall not know it.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Oh! my Daphne! now, or never,

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Strephon, fly my ſight for ever.

sp.speaker: Corid.
sp.l: I can no longer Sylvia wait thee,

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Corydon, be gone, I hate thee.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Curſe on this inchanted Grove.
We are all undone with Love.
We are all undone with Love.
Fly from this inchanted Grove.

div.head: Chorus after the Third Act.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Corydon is a noble Swain,
And too long has felt diſdain.
But ſince ſcorn I once did ſhow,
My Love I'm too proud to let him know.

sp.speaker: Daph
sp.l: Ah Sylvia! Sylvia! my Heart (like yours)
Pain from fooliſh Pride endures.
I angry with Strephon to day did appear,
And now long to reconcile:
Yet in pride for a time will ſeem ſevere,
Though it breaks my Heart the while.

div.stage: Enter Strephon, Corydon, Chorus of Shepheards. Daphne and Sylvia offer to go as they Enter.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Oh whither does my lovely Daphne fly?

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: How long will Sylvia Corydon deny?

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: It is will my kindneſs to remove:

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: And I ſhall never, never Love.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Oh! what has chang'd my Daphne's mind?

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Oh falſe, and cruel Woman-kind!

sp.speaker: 1 Shep.
sp.l: Come Shepheards do not complain.
See, ſee yonder a merry Train,
Of Gypſies dancing over the Plain.
Call e'm ſtraight, call e'm ſtraight to comfort theſe poor Swains.

div.l: Be proud, and diſdain e'm again.
Will be glad to be kind,
When they once are deſpiſed by the Men.

sp.speaker: 1 Shep.
sp.l: Hark, hark! in yonder woods the Satyrs play,
The Ecchoes bring their laughs this way.
They with ſome pleaſant ſport are pleas'd.
The wanton Demy-beaſts ſome Nymphs have ſeiz'd.
Laugh Shepheards, Laugh and ſing.
Joyful Tydings now we bring.
The fair Caliſtho is diſgrac'd;
Gods and Mortals hate the Chaſt.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: All this to me but little eaſe does give,

sp.speaker: Coryd.
sp.l: All joys are dead to me, why do I live?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: In death alone we eaſe ſhall find.

sp.speaker: Coryd.
sp.l: In death alone we eaſe ſhall find.

sp.speaker: Chor. of all.
sp.l: Oh falſe and cruel Woman-kind!

div.head: Chorus in the Fourth Act.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Oh! whither are our poor deſpairing Lover, gone?
I fear I have my Strephon ſlain,

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: And I my Corydon.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Oh my ſorrow! Oh my pain!
Could I my Strephon find:
Could I my deareſt Strephon find
I'd never be unkind.
I'd never be unkind to him again.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: And I, my Love would paſſionately own,
Could I find my Corydon.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Do I Dream? Do I Rave?
Look towards yonder Cave.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Our Shepheards come from yonder Cave.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Our Shepheards come from yonder Cave.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Our Shepheards come from yonder Cave.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: From empty pride I'le be free,
It ſhall bring no more miſchief upon me,
Since I Love as well as he,
I'le not hazard my joy,
In being fooliſhly coy,
It had like to have undone me.

div.stage: Daphne and Sylvia go and meet Strephon and Corydon: each brings in her Shepheard.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Dear Strephon, give deſpairing o're,
Unkindneſſes are gone,
I never will be cruel to thee more.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Nor I to Corydon.

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: O what kind God does Sylvia's hate remove?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: And made at length my Daphne grateful prove?

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: The God of Love.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: The God of Love.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: The gentle God of Love.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: The gentle God of Love.

sp.speaker: Coryd.
sp.l: Oh happy Tydings!

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Bleſſed hour!
Ever kind and gentle Pow'r.

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: Ever kind and gentle Pow'r.

div.stage: Enter Chorus of Shepheards, follow'd by Bacchuſſes.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Joy Shepheards Joy! Diana's diſgrac'd,
Love has had to day Revenge on the Chaſt.
The Bacchuſſes here our mirth to improve,
Come hither to follow the Triumphs of Love.
No mirth without Bacchus, nor joy without Love.

l.hi: Since all our grief thus joyfully ends,
Let each Shepheardeſs make her Shepheard amends
To the Temple let's go,
And then we will ſhow,
What every Lover, by Loving intends.

div.head: Chorus after the Fifth Act.
div.stage: Enter Strephon, Corydon, Daphne, Sylvia, Chorus of Shepheards, as from the Temple.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Happy Lovers! happy Live,
And all the Gods their bleſſings give.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Lead along, and with Delight,
Let us haſten on the Night.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: What Viſion's this is come to greet us?

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: See! the Night is come to meet us.

sp.speaker: 1 Afr.
sp.l: Stay gentle Swains be not afraid,
To ſee our Faces hid in ſhade.
We, but lately, were as fair,
As your Shepheardeſſes are.
Did not a frantick youth of late,
O'reſet the Chariot of the Sun?

sp.speaker: Cory.
sp.l: He did, and his deſerved Fate
He met when he had done.

sp.speaker: 1 Afr.
sp.l: It is he that hath undone us:
He powr'd whole ſtreams
Of melting Beams,
Red, and glowing hot upon us.
And now we range the World around,
To ſee if our loſt Beauty can be found.

sp.speaker: 3 Afr.
sp.l: Rejoyce, Rejoyce: our Beauty's found,
Our lovely White and Red,
To two chaſt Nymphs of Cynthia's Train is fled.
And they muſt Stars be crown'd:
And now inſtead of what we ſought,
Our black with us muſt fair be thought.

sp.speaker: All three.
sp.l: This happy Fate, who could Divine?
Our Beauty then in Heav'n muſt ſhine.

sp.speaker: 1 Afr.
sp.l: No loſers we ſhall prove,
By parting with our Red and White;
If Black will ſerve the turn of Love;
For Beauty's made for Loves delight.

sp.speaker: 4 Afr.
sp.l: See! See! the Nymphs are coming here.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: But Oh! what glorious Apparition's near?
The Clouds amazing Glories gild:
All the Clouds with Gods are fill'd.
And all the Gods appear.

div.stage: Caliſtho and Nyphe enter under a Canopy, ſupported by Africans; Immediately upon their entrante a Heav'n is diſcover'd, fill'd with Gods and Goddeſſes.
The whole, concludes with an Entry of Africans, and this Song.

l.hi: Must theſe be Starrs? and to Heaven remove,
Before they have taſted the pleaſures of Love.
That the Gods ſo ill, ſuch Beauty ſhould uſe!
What mighty Cost muſt Nature looſe?
I cannot ſo much Beauty ſhow,
But what I have, I'le better bestow.
Not upon Gods, or Glories above,
Or empty Renown, but Pleaſure and Love.
All pleaſure but Love, from our Hearts we'l be chacing,
We'l kindle our ſelves into Starrs with embracing,
We'l every moment our pleaſures renew,
Our Loves ſhall be flaming, and laſting and true.
